entries.title: 108 seconds of loneliness
entries.description:
Made using FlashPunk.

I procrastinated all day Saturday, so this is the product of about 12 hours work.

There was going to be a 108 second time limit on every level, but that got left by the wayside.

entries.title: Artifact Hunt
entries.description:
Gave up on my original idea early and just thought I'd push out *something* since it was my first LD. After I gave up my original idea I wanted to make a survival treasure hunt score attack game, but I wasn't really a fan of how it was coming and just churned this out. Still learning, I'll do better next time! Oh, and for 2 hours I spent trying to make a tads3 game, for fun. I didn't submit it and just was an experiment for fun to take a break from the 3d work.
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/04/24/tried-to-make-an-island-text-adventure/

as for my real entry:
shift to run
mouse + wasd to move/look
F5 toggles full screen
m to mute sound
r to restart
escape to exit (press twice)

eat bananas, don't starve.
find artifacts

entries.title: Awesome LifeBoat Game
entries.description:
Your a sailor on a steam powered lifeboat the HMS Awesome, it's dark and there are people who need saving.

The left and right keys rotate your boat and up starts your engine. 

Enjoy a 3 minute search and rescue mission.

entries.title: Capsize! feat Rep. Johnson vs. DJ Admiral
entries.description:
Running the game:
OS X: Just double-click Capsize!.app
Windows: Double-click Capsize!.bat

Linux/Source: You'll need to get the dependencies yourself, sorry. First, have ruby and rubygems, then:
gem install gosu
gem install chipmunk-ffi

Download and install chipmunk: http://files.slembcke.net/chipmunk/release/ChipmunkLatest.tgz

Then, cd into the game's folder, and:
ruby LD17.rb

About:

This game, which was inspired by recent comments made by a certain Congressman on the House Armed Services Committee, does not reflect any particular political beliefs, other than perhaps the belief that people sometimes say really, really dumb things. About islands.

Objective:

The object is to keep the island of Guam from capsizing for as long as possible. You accumulate points over time - more points the more stuff is on the island. Stuff will be air dropped whether you like it or not; you can call in a new building by left-clicking, or a soldier by right-clicking. You lose points if a soldier drowns, and the game ends when the island capsizes.

Wish List:

There was supposed to be more, like ordering soldiers to build or destroy buildings, or build flotation devices, but, I couldn't get there in time. There was also supposed to be a song, but I didn't allot enough time to learn to use GarageBand - if you sit at the title screen long enough, you can hear some of the samples I was going to use.

Known Bugs:
There's a bug with the soldiers where when they drown, they still move around, oops. This can lead to them 'drowning' over and over again, and you losing points for it each time. Ah, well.

Controls:
Left click drops a building, right click a soldier. Escape quits



Enjoy!

entries.title: Crowned in Doubt
entries.description:
Made with Pulpcore. Music with Ableton Live. 

Ominous lack of other sound effects thanks to Real Life.

I couldn't get the "islands of light" effect I wanted without crushing CPUs even worse, but it's pretty okay for a first attempt. It is "winnable".

Edit: Let me know if there are web hosting troubles, I have only tested it from one location.

entries.title: Cartograph
entries.description:
Cartograph
You control a ship navigating through a chain of mysterious islands. Your goal is the chart as many of of these islands as you can without crashing or running out of supplies. Additional detail is inside the included readme.txt.

Update About Graphics
It has come to my attention that the the game is not scaling up properly on some machines. This makes the graphics look extremely blurry, rather than blocky, which was the intent. This may have something to do with XP vs 7; I developed on 7, where it looks fine, but when tried on an XP machine, looked blurry. The game is still playable with the blurry graphics, it just doesn't look good at all (not that it looked "good" to start with, but you get me). As I alluded in my release notes below, I'm pretty much unavailable today (Sunday), so this is not something I'll be able to even try to fix. That's the problem with cutting an already short development time in half: little to no time spent testing or bug-fixing. I fully expect to be harshly down-graded by anyone who plays with the blurry graphics, as I should be. I suppose I'll have to chalk this one up to "lessons learned" and do better the next time. Sorry!

Notes
Made using Game Maker 8. My first time using it actually, though I have used previous versions in the past. I'm actively trying to learn some other game programming, namely C#/XNA and Objective-C/Cocos2D, but those are a long ways away from being something I enter any sort of competition with. This is my second LD attempt, with Caverns being the first. I was not even close to properly prepared for that one in retrospect; I didn't even start Friday night, and goofed around a bit on Saturday, before realizing Sunday morning that I was in trouble. I wound up with about a 66% completed game that was about 33% of my original vision. I wanted to really try at the next one, but after months of waiting, I gut punched when I found out that Exploration was taking place on the weekend I was moving. Arg!

But hey, there's always next time right? Believe it or not, I was screwed again: this weekend, I had to fly out mid-day Sunday for business over the next couple of days. Unbelievable! I swear that four out of five weekends, I just hang around the house with nothing special to do. But for some reason, LD conspires against me. I was all set to skip out yet again, when I decided, screw it, I'm going to at least TRY. I scaled back all ideas I had to the bare minimum possible: an Atari-esque arcade game. Something with no music, leaves-plenty-to-the-imagination graphics, play time of under a minute, and so on. And I made it! In retrospect, the game is actually incredibly basic for the amount of time I spent on it - I have a feeling the more experienced people on here could whip this thing out in hours, rather than a full day - but hey, everyone's got to start somewhere, eh?

entries.title: Evil Lair Command
entries.description:
Premise: Protect your island lair from those pesky government agents.

My first successfully completed (for some low value of success) Ludum Dare.

It's in javascript/html5/canvas, so you need a modern browser to play it. See http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/04/27/evil-lair-command-compatibility-testing/ for compatibility. In short, it works in the latest Firefox, Chrome, and Safari.

I may add a link to an improved version at the URL above, but will obviously leave the LD17 version up unchanged... Unless it really does add your computer to a bot net (hint, attempt to play with javascript turned off or view the source).

Tools:
notepad++, Gimp, Firebug, google (for figuring out how this javascript and canvas stuff works. It's been years since I wrote any javascript, and it certainly didn't have any of these weird-quasi-oop thingies in it)

entries.title: Floating Islands
entries.description:
Instructions are simple, use the mouse as direction to jump, press and hold the left click to charge jump power, release it to jump. You have to reach the flag. Good luck!

You must have a video card with hardware acceleration capabilities. 

It could fail on Mac because of a bug on a library (lwjgl) to access OpenGL on Java. It is fixed on the latest version of this library but I have not updated the game to use that one, yet.

On http://blog.gemserk.com/games/floating-islands/latest is the current development version, for now is the same of the entry but I want to update some things on these days.

UPDATE: I have updated the lwjgl lib, so now people with Mac could play the game using the webstart link.

entries.title: Galapagos
entries.description: Unfinished but playable... it was a good time! Src included in zip, or visit ld48jovoc on google code.

entries.title: Island Balance
entries.description:
This game was made as a Glorious Trainwreck in the last two hours of LD17 using Unity 3D. Sound effects made with Sfxr, music with Musagi, textures with Paint.Net.

Your goal is to roll a ball as far as you can across rickety platforms in the water without falling in. You have to move quickly, because the platforms will tip over.

Here's my timelapse video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pvvT9Xcr4nQ

Controls:
WASD or arrow keys to move, Spacebar to jump.

entries.title: Island Conflict
entries.description:
You are Mr. Blue. Island domination is a race against your arch enemy Mr. Red. Claim land as fast as you can. You may need to cross water, build ships with wood you receive from chopping trees. Beware, you can only tread on your own or unclaimed land.

Remember, only the winner wins!


Control fully with mouse, in game press W to wait a move and R to restart with a new island. Islands are never the same!

entries.title: Island Hopping
entries.description:
The updated version includes double jumping now for a bit more reasonable difficulty (you can of course still download the original that was uploaded before the deadline). I still have a lot more tweaks to try but I have a sociology paper to write, so this will have to do until I get some more time.

IMPORTANT: While in mid-air, the direction you're looking affects your trajectory. So if you need to jump a bit further aim up, or if you're going to overshoot an island aim down. It takes a bit of getting used to, but I think (hope...) it's fairly intuitive. (in the updated version this effect is toned down a bit, but still present)

Okay, this is "Island Hopping", a first person platformer-ish thing (with islands!).

The goal is to jump from island to island getting as many points as possible without falling into the water (different islands give different points and there are also various powerups and bonuses).

The controls are simply mouse to look and space to jump (you automatically move forward in the direction the camera is looking). The islands are placed procedurally.

As time goes by your speed will increase and the islands will become further apart, higher difficulty modes accelerate this process (in addition to spawning smaller islands).

See the readme for more specific info.

Here's a video of it http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dUY9C67HARc

Here's the timelapse:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sGcEMPxATM

UPDATE: Thanks for the feedback so far! I'm definitely going to keep working on this for a couple weeks, so I'll tweak the difficulty a bit more, allow you to turn off the music (it is pretty repetitive...), add online high scores (I almost have this working right now...) and whatever else I can.

entries.title: Island of Bounty
entries.description:
Unfinished entry that I plan on continuing.
Arrow keys to move, X to fire arrows.

entries.title: Island Raiders
entries.description:
UPDATE:  The issue on Windows XP machines was fixed.  Its probably too late now though, but the issue was caused when I compiled the game using py2exe on my windows 7 machine.  Compiling on a windows xp machine fixed the issue.


The game is incomplete.  The only thing you can do is 

1.) select your island with the factory on it
2.) when you have at least 1 boat built by the factory you can click the 'Move 100% of Boats' button and then click on any other island to move the boats to it.
3.) moving the boats to the one enemy island (red) will destroy one of the enemy boats and one of your boats

Development Tools:
Blender
Gimp
Python Ogre library
Eclipse IDE w/Pydev plugin for editing python source

THE PY2EXE HAS BEEN FIXED AND DOWNLOAD SIZE REDUCED.  IT SHOULD WORK ON ALL WINDOWS MACHINES.

entries.title: Island Repair Man
entries.description:
TO RUN ON WINDOWS: Extract all files to a new folder, then run the exe in the Release folder.

TO RUN ELSEWHERE: Source code should build on most platforms; only dependency is Irrlicht. But, not tested, and there's no makefile or anything.

The island has broken apart into white glowing pieces in a freak storm of spiky red things! Chaos! Calamity! Climate change! Who shall save us?

Have no fear, brave citizens! ISLAND REPAIR MAN is here!

Golly gosh! Thanks, Island Repair Man!

RULES:
* You are the blue circle on one of the white "island pieces".
* Click on another white "island pieces" to jump to it.
* Visit every island piece at least once.
* Don't jump through red things!

My best is level 7, can you beat it?

entries.title: Islands Survival
entries.description:
You are a robot. There is a giant ship and little speeding robots after you. Survival is your only option.

Score points by jumping on little speeding robots, letting shots hit blocks, and the crystal getting destroyed.

I didn't spend a lot of time on it, and honestly, I just wanted it finished. I could've done more in polishing it but I just didn't want to deal with it anymore. No music or sound effects, don't know how to make either. High score does not get saved outside of game. Works on XP. Cannot guarantee it will work on any other Windows version.

EDIT: Changed download links. Should work now.

entries.title: Land Ho!
entries.description:
A game about sailing around and visiting islands.

Unfortunately this is unfinished... have fun just sailing around and discovering randomly generated islands. There's nothing else to do.

Controls:
A/D - turn ship
W/S - Increase/decrease sail
Q/E - Adjust sails

entries.title: Needles
entries.description:
Educational platformer. You will fail, and learn at the same time! XD

Arrows: move
Shift: jump

Note: This was created in a couple of hours, after I finished 'Stuck', my main game for the weekend. :3

entries.title: Risky Island
entries.description:
Well, it's done! Not only that, but I did it without a single other blog post or going in the IRC (I smell a 5/5 on community). This game is also incomplete in a lot of ways, and seems to be buggy, but I didn't have time to fix it! Probably because I spent most of my time slacking off as I didn't really like the theme that much. Anyways, hope you enjoy somewhat idling while waiting to get more attack in the game!

Instructions:

*The land you own is blue. You can click on it to select it, and anything you can attack will turn red.
*When you attack something, you'll attack it by ((your attack power - 1) divided by 2).
*You will be able to see more of the island as you take over more ground
*Normal land will get + 1 every 15 seconds, while big land will get + 2.

Resources aren't yet finished, and even if they were, you wouldn't be able to do anything with them. You also can't transfer troops from land to land, so this probably makes the game impossible in this state! Anyways, that pretty much covers it. Have fun!

Note: The game is SUPER SIZE. Hope this doesn't affect your gameplay, but it probably will!

entries.title: Stuck
entries.description:
Short exploration maze type of game.

Find the boat to win!
If your heart vanishes, you get warped back to the last house you visited.
The more houses you find, the stronger your heart gets.
Arrow keys to move, escape to quit.

(No music, sorry.)

entries.title: The Adventures of Archie Pegalo
entries.description:
Another platformer for the heap ^^ 

Control Archie Pegalo as he escapes from his desert island. Did this from scratch with SDL + OpenGL. Warning, it's quite difficult.

Timelapse: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WHlXEjBDtNI

entries.title: They Came From the Ocean
entries.description:
bluescrn's attempt at a little 48hr FPS. Not really 100% finished, but fairly playable

An island with black smokey monsters... surely nobody's done that before? :)

Controls

Mouse 		  - Look/Turn
WASD or arrowkeys - Move/strafe
Left  Mouse 	  - Shoot
Right Mouse 	  - Jump
Esc 		  - Quit
F1 		  - Toggle Fullscreen

Requires DX9, with a Shader 2.0 card or above.

It's very inefficient, excessive amounts of draw calls, so may need a fairly quick PC!

I apologise in advance for those that have to hunt around for the right D3DX lib!

entries.title: Ascention
entries.description:
I have verified that all the physics work correctly in Firefox 3.5.8, and the game is completable.  There are several jumps that are only barely possible, and others that are only barely impossible to make.

As people are having some trouble with the first three levels, I've provided a description of the correct path under the "Spoilers" link.  Several people that have thought there's a physics bug simply haven't found the right path.  There are lots of jumps that almost work in this game.

Unfortunately, the only indication that you've reached the end is that the clock in the upper-right corner stops.

entries.title: Atollery
entries.description:
Paint by Numbers meets Tron in this puzzle game where you place bridges between islands to make one winding path through each island cluster.

EDIT: Source is in the windows download, you get it no matter what.

entries.title: Elementary My Dear Watson
entries.description:
Elementary My Dear Watson

I am writting this 10 minutes before the deadline of Ludum Dare #17. This is my entry. The theme was islands, and the point of this game is to guide your boats (golden ones) to battle against the evil black boats. You can do this by controlling the elements of nature! Left click to create a ripple in water, and right click to change wind direction. Boats will battle each other automatically. Oh and there's islands. The total work on this is aproximately 8 hours since I was working all weekend, I couldn't get more in. It's far from polished, and the code is ugly, but I plan on making a more elaborate version later on. Oh and I ripped the idea off from there: http://www.squidi.net/three/entry.php?id=77

If it's worth anything, this was my first Ludum Dare.

entries.title: Every Man Is An Island
entries.description:
A Unity based platformer, based on the buoyant effect of dead bodies!

Didn't get half as much done as I wanted to, but alas time was close and i'm happy with the art and interaction of the stuff that is there!

Update 28/04/10:

Didn't have any time to fix some of the problems until now, but the windows version should work properly, the collision problems in all of them should be fixed (remember unity kids, don't move colliders with transform.position even if you've only got 5 minutes left in a compo!).

Please re-download the windows version and review it again, alternatively clear your cache for the web version.

entries.title: Eyelands
entries.description:
You are stranded on an island in the middle of the ocean with angry natives who are out to get you. Find the hatchet, chop down big bamboo trees and start a fire in the fire pit to survive the night. How many natives can you kill? How many days can you survive? Dying at least once might be interesting.

-If you do not get a fire going before night, the natives will instantly kill you!

Hint: the hatchet is up and to the left a bit

Note 1: Even with a fire going the natives will attack you, but the chance of attack decrease.

Note 2: The game does not currently restart when you die as I did not have time to get that in. For now just hit refresh on your browser. *fixed*

Note 3: I am aware that occasionally when throwing spears, your character will occasionally get hit by them.

Note 4: I had a bunch more trees and some grass, but for some reason when I went for the final build, Unity killed all my extra trees and the grass was not responding to the lighting correctly. *fixed except for grass*

I may rework note 1 in some manner - just not sure yet.

entries.title: Island Airline
entries.description:
Try #4 - So, I've added just about every file I can imagine being a dependency.  Hopefully, people can play it now.

Try #3 - So the setup was an attempt to fix the problem, but it didn't work.  The problem has something to do with the dependence on SDL.Net but I'm baffled at this point.  I won't be using it again, that's for sure.

entries.title: Island Defender
entries.description:
Controlls:
-A: Move Left
-D: Move Right
-W: Jump
-Mouse: Aim and shoot

The premise for this game is, simply, to defend your island from nearby attackers. Why, you ask? Well, what would you do if your island was being attacked? 

NOTE: I may have said I was going to add a boss, but sadly, there was no time. :(

Thanks on the comments, guys. My goal here was to make a simple, frantic, game that you can jump into at any time and have lots of fun, and I think I acheived something like that. 

For the music, I  used PxTone, if you wanted to know.

entries.title: Island of Darkness
entries.description:
I didn't get anywhere near finished. Don't play this, it's horrible. :P

Problems: Enemies don't hurt. Falling in water is lame. There's some collision bugs.

entries.title: Islands of the Stone God
entries.description:
Tools:
 - code: FlashDevelop (Flash ActionScript 3)
 - sound: sfxr + musagi 
 - graphics: Inkscape + Gimp

Libraries:
 - Flixel v1.25
 - TweenLite v6.21

This is a story of a non-specified insignificant stone god, who dwells in distant dark waters, near a group of islands.
Once in a while he climbs out of his cozy abyss to look upon the world and all the new islands and things,
that came to existence since his last visit. He likes to mangle and twist destinies.
 
I had a lot of fun creating various creatures and their interaction rules, I wish I had just one more day to add more content.
 
GOAL:
	
	Get 15 achievements, have fun.

  Move islands over the map, so that the living creatures could traverse between them.
	When you're done, enter the abyss to finish the level.
	
	In each of 7 levels, new islands appear, bearing new items and creatures.
	
	Creatures interact with items and each other according to given rules. Accomplishing some of the interactions will get you an achievement.
	
	Minimap (you're white, abyss is red) and stone plaques (with tips) may help you.

CONTROLS:
 
  CURSOR KEYS - movement
  X - jump

entries.title: Isolated Empire
entries.description:
^ Source included in that download.
Compilation instructions:
1. Get Lazarus .9.28.3 beta / SVN / daily with FPC 2.4.0.
2. Download Andorra from andorra.sourceforge.net
3. Fix whatever errors Andorra's source may have
4. Recompile the openGL lib if on Linux
5. Make sure the Lazarus project file knows where Andorra is
6. If on linux, download and extract the Linux libs to the folder.
7. If on linux, search and replace ".dll" with ".so" [I haven't configured the source to be cross-platform without any changes]
** This game can only be compiled for Win/Linux due to Andorra.

Isolated Empire starts off with the premise that you and a few others have managed to strand yourself on an island, with no way way off other than the resources on the island and your bare hands.

**** THERE IS NO TUTORIAL IN-GAME, READ THIS ****
Basic controls:
Mouse: Interactivity
Arrow Keys: Moving the map

1. Once your world has finished generating, click on the tile with the flag on it. From here, you can create more villagers. Villagers are the people that are with you, and are now inhabiting this island.
2. Click on other tiles with objects on them to harvest. Simply press the corresponding button that pops up.
3. IMPORTANT: Your villagers require constant sustenance. Keep a close eye on your food and water supplies, or your people will die! *** The only way to get food is to create a farm (from the bottom of the screen)
4. So you've got some villagers now. Awesome. Now look at the top right of the screen. You should see numbers like "1/3/10" The first number is the number of villagers _working_. The second is the total number of villagers, and the third is how many villagers you can create.
5. Oops you've hit your population cap? At the bottom of the screen you can click the house and click a tile to place it (must be empty, as with all others). Note that you can only have up to 250 villagers.
6. Collect enough resources to build a raft and get away!
7. Watch your time limit! (Upper right)

Created with:
Free Pascal Compiler (via Lazarus IDE)
Andorra 2D [GFX renderer]
SDL/SDL_Mixer [Sound player]
Anvil Studio [Original tunes]
GXSCC [Warped those ugly anvil studio midis into 8bit deliciousness]
GIMP [GFX]
Media-Convert.com [Wav->Ogg conversion]
sfxr [SFX]
Free Audio Editor [Bump up volume of music]

I'm sure this thing is laggy as poo, and quite possibly buggy. (I submitted this barely within reach of the deadline with extremely minimal testing)

I somehow doubt this game is beatable. I meant to add more HQ's you could build so you could have closer places for villagers to collect from, but I didn't have time to put that in.

When you assign a villager to gather a resource, it will actually walk across the tiles (albeit invisibly) to its destination, gather some of the resource, and head back.
Bugs:
1. The villagers aren't chosen closest to the destination. You may have 1 town closer to a resource, but another town's villager might wander over.
2. The stop button doesn't work

I plan on working on this more even after judging, etc.

entries.title: Lonesome Flotsam
entries.description:
Lonesome Flotsam
Ludum Dare 17 version by Caleb Jewett

Get ready to fight for survival! It's your job to control a lifeform so overgrown with hair it is practically unrecognizable. Your good friend, the protagonist, is so filled with fright that she? he? it? can not be left alone for an instant without spinning into a crazed, whirling insanity. You'll have to take the lead.

Scour the landscape for blueprints and materials to give you and your friend the tools to survive and, perhaps, even escape. Sample the local delicacies: crab and purple boar. If you can gather enough wood to build a raft, you might, MIGHT be able to see home again. Or, you might be forced to face an awful truth.

WASD to attack.
Arrow keys to move.
Use the mouse in the workshop.
Get at least 20 trees and the raft blueprints to build a raft, escape, and win the game! ...maybe...

1.1 VERSION:
I think I fixed the permanent invulnerability bug, I added a second workshop and some boars to make hunting easier, I fixed a room change bug, and renamed some stuff. Also, the good ending now requires armor. I don't think either ending is accessible in the LD17 version due to bugs :(.

1.2 Changes:
The new workshop actually works! It should no longer kill you!
Raft recipe moved so it is visible and obtainable.
Your conscience may rest more easily: boars will no longer moan so loudly when you 
kill them.
Continues added by popular demand! Please don't tell the wilderness protection
officials, they will ruin things for all of us.

I named this game after a song I made. You can hear the chiptune version of it here: http://8bitcollective.com/music/Pyrrhuloxia/Lonesome+Flotsam+%288+Bit+Remix%29/

Really hope someone manages to finish, so I've updated to 1.2!

entries.title: Pirates
entries.description:
This is a quite simple game about Pirates, a treasure, Robinson Crusoe
and an island.

Timelapse here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMf1bfnPV-E

The goal is very simple: Robinson Crusoe, alone on his island
has to protect his treasure form an army of pirates.

It is written in java, with lwjgl library. Graphic are made
with Inkscape and Gimp.

REQUIRED:

- Windows XP or later, Linux, may work on MacOS but not tested
- Java Runtime Environment 1.6 (may work with 1.5 but not tester)
- Opengl support (hardware or software)

CONTROLS:

- use arrows to move
- Space for hit
- Right control for BIG hit! (can be re-done only 10 seconds after using it)
- Echap for quit
- After game over you can quit by pressing "Echap" or restart by pressing "Space"

SCORE:

It is printed at the top of the screen. There is more and more
pirates and score grow faster and faster.

LAUNCH:

- On Linux: go to the directory with a shell and type "./pirates.sh"
- On windows: go to the directory whith a shell and type "pirates.bat"
- On MacOS: I don't know the exact command. If you are familiar with java
see the script content, and put native/macosx in the Java.library.path

Enjoy!

entries.title: Radio Silence
entries.description:
Made at the Cambridge meet up! My game from day one didn't work out (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcHihVVheM8), so I started from scratch on Sunday morning. 

(Special thanks to Dock and PerrinAshcroft for answering my constant questions about Unity, and to everyone who attended the Cambridge meet up!)

entries.title: Roach Route
entries.description:
A very liberal interpretation of the theme. Warning: Has creepy crawlies!

Move with the arrow keys, and throw a torch with the spacebar. 

Objective: Collect the treasure and then escape!

Play it online!
http://johnnesky.com/index.php?page=roachroute

All of the audio was made in less than an hour with my in-progress synthesizer for Mac:
http://code.google.com/p/nuzynth/downloads/list

I spent a few hours on Saturday learning how to use Pixel Bender for a very simple effect that I didn't know any other way to do in Flash. :P

The source is at:
http://www.johnnesky.com/shaktool_LD17_RoachRoute.zip

To compile, download the source, install the Flex SDK, and then run:
mxmlc RoachRoute.as --target-player=10.0.0

Hint: Plan ahead.

entries.title: Simcano
entries.description: Make your islands avoiding the magma!

entries.title: SkyLands
entries.description:
SkyLands is about islands in the sky. You play as Vapor the Airboarder who is trying to collect all the lightning bolts to get the Wind Machines back up and going so everyone can once again airboard from island to island.

Game has 2 levels.
Controls:
up arrow moves up
down arrow moves down
left arrow moves left
right arrow moves right

up and down arrows to navigate through menus
enter or space to choose options in the menu

Ctrl will turn off/on sound
Shift will turn off/on full screen

entries.title: Stranded!
entries.description:
Use WASD to move, space to pick up a banana.

Don't die of hunger, please.

entries.title: The Floor Is Lava
entries.description:
Arcade-style platformer(?) - jump between the stone islands that sink in the lava. 

For great awesome.

Additional notes and tips:
* The ice cubes get farther apart the longer the game goes on, and you get bonus points for letting them scroll offscreen rather than collecting them. 
* Islands move faster the closer to the edge you are, but there's always the danger of the island shrinking out from under you, so don't get TOO close.
* An island's movement can add a bit of extra momentum to your jumps.
* The lava pulses in time to the music. This has no gameplay effect, but looks cool.
* The kobold is a character from an earlier game I made, Dragondot, in case you're wondering what that's about.
* I'm in technical violation of a submission guideline. The "death poof" sound in this game is the same sound kobolds make when they die in Dragondot, as an inside joke/continuity nod. Please disregard that particular sound when considering your Audio vote.

entries.title: The Forgotten Isles
entries.description:
Use the arrow keys to explore the maze-covered islands.

You find yourself on a beach, unsure of how you arrived there, or why you're on this island. The terrain fades into existence as you explore, and disappears after you've left.

You're memories slowly slip away, being forgotten one by one. Find familar memories which have manifested themselves in physical form on the island to help restore your thoughts, and perhaps your sanity.

Finding a way off these islands may prove difficult, because of both the natural maze environment and the rehashed memories of how you came to be on the Forgotten Isles.

entries.title: Whales of Aelia
entries.description:
Use the mouse to play.

This game was made with FlashPunk. I started about an hour late and took about 15 minutes extra at the end! Hopefully that isn't excessive... Just fessing up =)

*** SECOND CONFESSION (EDIT) *** I (quite unintentionally) used an image from NASA in this game. It's seen off the end of the world (modified with a gimp filter). It wasn't my intention to break the rules, honestly I was just in the middle of a "creative flow" and I have used public domain NASA images before in projects, so just naturally thought of using one. It doesn't "feel like" cheating to me but with the discussion of the rules I realized that this does go against the all-original-content rule so I wanted to post that here, too! Peas!

*** EDIT: ***

- There is a definite goal to the game.
- Game world is randomly generated so...
- If you can't figure it out the first time, please give it another couple tries.

Thanks for the comments everybody! I don't want to spell things out too much as that goes against the idea. I am really happy with how this turned out...

entries.title: Wow, Islands And Stuff!!
entries.description: You are a super floating island super explorer! Adventure through SIX (count 'em!) levels in search of a palm tree to call your own! Warp from island to island through the power of something! Precarious platforming! Useless coins! YEAH!

entries.title: Zombie Grinder
entries.description:
IF YOU CAN'T RUN THIS, PLEASE EMAIL ME: demonpants [at] gmail.com . Java naturally is not write once port anywhere like it claims. I'd like to figure out whatever wacky porting problems might exist. Thanks!

***************EDIT:
Realized that I could change the download link titles, so now it's more obvious how to get the version with sound (it used to be linked at the bottom of this post). If you haven't played with sound yet, please do so! I only included the option the first time because the sound version is 35mb.
*************/EDIT

This is Zombie Grinder!

You are on an island trying to escape a zombie onslaught. It comes from the left - you've got to keep running towards the right! Eventually you'll reach your ship, at which case you're safe and you've won!

You can't be killed by individual zombies; the worst they can do is slow you down. However, if you touch the horde, then you die! You may also see other islanders fighting off zombies - they're great distractions!

Move with the arrow keys.
Punch and kick with Z and X.
Jump by pressing Z and X simultaneously.
Double tap an arrow to run.

Enjoy!

Uses Java with Java Webstart (all Java-enabled OS's should be able to run it). Runs on OpenGL using LWJGL.
Edit - I changed the download to a Java Webstart to make it easier on everyone. Also added a couple more screenshots.

entries.title: Bouncecrab, Starfish Island
entries.description:
A very short game written entirely from scratch in Standard ML using SDL.

Now available for Windows!  Also, the Mac version is now statically linked against the GMP library, so if you had trouble before, please try it again.

entries.title: Dinosaur Vs the islands!
entries.description: Well... It was made in less than 8 hours, so please enjoy my epic tale of self discovery and enlightenment. Now with source code!

entries.title: Hungry for Island
entries.description:
Shoot forks down at the islands to destroy them--that is your only goal. (Try to conserve forks if you want, plastic is an oil derivative you know!) Move the mouse around to move the crosshairs, and turn on your speakers for some fanfare and sounds effects! Press escape to quit, if you really want to.

There are six levels included. This game was originally intended to be so much more, but then, aren't most of these games? Anyways, have fun!

Started late Saturday, but I got it done! Made with glfw, FMOD, Code::Blocks, Photoshop, and Musagi + sfxr (thanks DrPetter!).

entries.title: I HATE ISLANDS
entries.description:
A self-biographical adventure of nonsense.

You control a helicopter and must eliminate every last island.
There are 4 levels in different world locations and with projectile throwing palm trees and mermaids.

Try to beat the Argentinian level!

[Dework in progress]

entries.title: i thought we had a thing
entries.description:
Made in Flash|ActionScript using FlashDevelop and Paint.net. No sound.

Frameworks: Box2D, some code from my previous LD games.

Click on the game once to get focus, then use the arrow keys to move and the '1' key as directed.

--

If you complete all of the quests, the yellow pointer will disappear. That's the end of the game. Congratulations! You are a winner.

--

This game is lacking in gameplay. I never found something fun for the player to do, so I would love to hear your suggestions. Most of my time went into the quest system.

entries.title: Island Abduction
entries.description:
EDIT: I seem to have misread the rules and disqualified myself. The part about sound libraries being allowed if you remix their content somehow carried over to graphics in my brain. I even had a few hours at the end I could have spent in GIMP drawing crappy islands. Oh well, I still had a good time, live and learn!

Programmed on Linux in C++ with SDL. Makefile included. Haven't tried to get it to compile on other platforms, compatibility patches (and other patches, and comments, suggestions, insults etc) welcome.

Controls: q quits, ctrl for gravity gun, space to jump, left-right to move. 5 levels are included (level 5 is drastically different than the others, so play through them!) Added an OSX port (based on fink's SDL), don't have access to a windows box.

The collision detection code was the most complicated part, and it's still buggy as hell, but I don't have time to fix it further.

My first compo, had a blast! Looking forward to the next one.

entries.title: Island Jumper
entries.description:
I guess I'm done. Pretty happy with it. I could probably keep going a little longer but I stop when I stop enjoying working, which is now, dig?

Arrows move
Space to jump
Anything else to throw shovels

Find clues to figure out where to jump
Get treasure.
Be awesome.

entries.title: Islands!?! Curses!?!
entries.description:
My first Ludum Dare entry

You play as voodoo witch doctor going from island to island to capture evil spirits. Guide him around the islands to scare away spirits. Study the spirits to learn how they move (or read the tutorial). Trap them by dropping magical Voodoo Wards by right clicking. Chase them into a corner and grab them.

This is actaully my first XNA game and I made the rookie mistake of not having my environment sorted out to get everything properly deployed. Curses!

The game get's the "It works on my machine" Seal. I think the only way to get it to work is to have the XNA Game Studio 4.0 CTP. Let me know if you get it working.

Requirements:
.NET Framework 4.0
XNA Game Studio 4.0 CTP

Methods:
Dev: Built in XNA Game Studio 4.0 CTP, .NET 4.0 Using VS 2010 Pro RC
Art: Paint.NET

entries.title: Islands: Through the Sweep of Stars
entries.description:
UPDATE: The php source code - which is very little actual code - is available at the source link below. I recommend against reading it, as the source contains spoilers, but go ahead if you want to know any of the answers. The rest of the source is just HTML and can be viewed through your browser.

---

I decided I wanted to make a simple web game for this contest. Instead, I tried to focus on making some content (with varying success). I didn't have too much time during the weekend, but I'm relatively happy with this anyhow. It was a fun game to make.

I do hope it's at least somewhat enjoyable. If it's too tricky, you can get hints by viewing each page's source. I'd enjoy seeing somebody complete the game, as the end screen is the part of the game I'm happiest with. :)

entries.title: Jetpack Island
entries.description: It's not finished, but it's pretty cool.  Essentially, you collect fuel cells to fly around, destroy enemies, and escape the islands.  Controls are describe in the readme.txt file.

entries.title: Jump Pirate
entries.description:
Jump Pirate is a silhouette platformer about exploration and precision jumping. You play a small pirate in an oversized hat who is alone on an island. Help him to explore his surroundings and, hopefully, find a way off the island. The game autosaves every time you reach a checkpoint and every time you die too.

(No, he can't swim. The game wouldn't be very challenging if he could.)

EDIT: Second bugfix update (the first bugfix accidentally reverted to a previous version, which made the game work even worse than before :D ). It should work perfectly now. Again, if you experience graphical oddities press "Q" to deactivate the grass effects.

Source requires Game Maker and only runs on Windows.

To those who are stuck on the final level, take a look at this video walkthrough:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6x58LUilwRk

entries.title: Keytrader
entries.description:
Keytrader is an experimental trading game that makes you play Twister on your keyboard.  Only tutorial levels are complete.

Only had 8 hours to make it.  Bad bad weekend.

entries.title: Loneliness
entries.description:
An experimental, minimalistic microgame about loneliness.

Hopefully the theme tie-in should be clear.


HINT: At the beginning of the game, you need to go UP.

NOTE: I DO plan on adding some minimalistic music at some point... for the time being, try playing the game while listening to a song you feel goes with the title :) 


Congrats to everyone who submitted a game, or learned something, or had a good time :). I've seen some amazing looking stuff on the front page, and am really looking forward to playing as many of these games as I can. I love the community here. Best to everyone,

Jordan

entries.title: Mad Hatter Island
entries.description:
Knocked up in 2h for Ludum Dare 17.
Hasn't got any sound. (yeah I know)
It's short and sweet and is set on an island.

:D

arrows+space = move
esc quits
f9 takes screenshot
it's completable but rather challenging :)

Source is included in the main zip

entries.title: Napolon et la punition mystrieuse le du diable
entries.description:
CONTROL (WASD)  and "ENTER"
(sometimes holding jump button helps)
good luck.
if the jump looks impossible try holding jump button and things will be okay.
thanks for the comments...
(you can find me here http://twitter.com/Scandinavianair
soon I'll have a place with the other games I made)

entries.title: Pedestrian Voter
entries.description:
In Pedestrian Voter, you must lead a young man across perilous roads by using the traffic Islands so that he may get to the Polling Station and vote in the general election.

I didn't want to make a game about an island like most other people, so I decided to make one about traffic islands.

entries.title: Pirate-Go-Round
entries.description:
Wily pirates locked in a skirmish to the death! A two-player game, written in Processing. Requires Java, and be sure to give the applet plenty of time to load.  

There have been some reported problems with the Windows version; as I do not own a Windows machine, I can't really do much about it.  It did work on the one Windows computer I tried it on, during the 48-hour creation period.

Note:  I spent my first 24 hours working on an unrelated game, so this is more like a 24-hour-game.

=====================================================

My submission seems to have gotten deleted; I'm not sure what happened.  I hope that the the previous comments I received (which are very helpful -- thanks!) did not also get deleted.  If it was deleted for an actual reason, as opposed to a fluke in the system, please leave a comment to let me know what I did wrong.  Thanks!

entries.title: Poke-Slayer
entries.description:
My first Ludum Dare and I end up with a pokemon game ... Well this is suppose to turn out just great.

You know the feeling that you've just got enough of pokemon? I had the feeling years ago and it has not ended! So now is the time to go out for the greater good and destroy those beasts! I won't say it will be easy but I believe in you doing it! I have big expectations for you, good sir!

Anyways - the principle is simple and you just have to sail to Islands, kill pokemons, sell their skin, buy more ammo, kill more pokemons (and yes, the game will end).

The controls are simple and you use arrows to sail ship. Escape to leave shop. Numbers for the res but it is explained during game.

There is a windows, linux32 and linux64 executable so no reasons not to try it dudes - took some effort to get the windows one though.

I hope you'll enjoy it - I've at least enjoyed making it :)

// Sune

Ps. This game has theme song - you can hear it as long as you have the 3 introducing slides so take it easy on those ;)!

Pps. I have tried to cross-compile it to windows - which was not easy - but it seems like there is a small problem - instead of detecting the sides as wall it just shuts down - I haven't been able to fix it as I have not clue of why it's happening -_- Also there's some weird exits in Windows but it's really unexplainable but it works most of the time :)

***********************************************************
Written in C++ with SDL bindings and use of SDL_mixer and SDL_ttf
***********************************************************

Checked the links - should work just fine

***********************************************************

Found I had to upload the source so here it is - it ended up like crap due to my lack of overview and more than microchip programming ... Anyways - enjoy if you want to read it and sorry for it wasn't uploaded in the beginning - didn't know I was suppose too :)

entries.title: Rising Sea Levels
entries.description:
The idea:
Rescue people from procedurally generated islands while sea levels are steadily rising.

What it turned out to be:
UNFINISHED. Throughout the LD, I really had no idea where I was going gameplay-wise, so I toyed around with gfx but found no good use for it later. Basically, all I have now is a little fragment shader demo with minimal user interaction.

Controls:
WASD to control your boat
E to pick up nearby people
Q to drop off passengers

If you want to run the Ruby source, you'll need
gem install gosu
gem install opengl
Didn't manage to provide a standalone OSX app yet, hopefully I can supply it later.

entries.title: Roller-Derby 20XX: Mega Islands of Awesome
entries.description:
In the year 20XX the universe is in conflict. You are the sole jammer, defender of the world. Race atop metallic sky islands and win points for all of humanity.

Skate hard. Skate fast. The world is counting on you.

Roller-Derby 20XX: Mega Islands of Awesome was developed in Flash Builder 4 using the Flixel 2.35 library. Graphics were developed in Photoshop CS3. Music was developed in GarageBand. Sound effects were done in cfxr and Audacity.

Total development time: ~22hrs.

Soundtrack, Timelapse, Postmortem and more info: http://www.refrag.com/game-dev/roller-derby-20xx/

entries.title: ROW, FUCK!!!
entries.description:
An Atomic bomb has exploded and your only salvation is a boat. You have to row with all your strength to survive.

If you row hard enough you can crush some islands.

Use "A" to row to the left and "L" to row to the rigth.

Made in Game Maker

entries.title: Turtle Ferry
entries.description: A simple game where you ferry cats to safety! Press Space to restart, press Escape to exit.

entries.title: Waves
entries.description: Done in considerably less than 48 hours, as I wasn't able to clear my weekend.  Alternate title: "Oh, Shit!  Sharks!"

entries.title: Windsurfing !
entries.description:
EDIT: finally found how to edit my entry :) So let me replace the original link with the patch described in :
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/04/27/windsurfing-patch-1-adds-keyboard-control/

So, it's my simplistic windsurfing simulation. Nothing much to do for now. Enjoy moving on the waves :) The goal here is to achieve a correct control scheme for a windsurf board, and I have implemented a 'realistic' control where you control the board and the sail separately (but for now the turning is simply based on the feet banking, not on the sail longitudinal angle.. 

1.Make sure to install the vc10 redist included in the archive
2. read the readme
3. enjoy ! control with left and right joysticks on gamepad, or S, F, and arrow keys on keyboard.

What I'll be doing next: jump, fall, and cool surfing waves. Oh by the way I only learnt about Windsurfing MMX _after_ the compo. (but their game is arcade, mine will be a sim :)

Source for the game is included. Source for my "engine" (mostly gluing the libraries below together) is not yet available - but I'll try to get it to you asap. The game source is small, readable (and interesting?) though - please share your programmer comments :)

I'll try to upload my Ubuntu build too (but after the Windows DLL deployment issues I'm tired of deploying..)

Made with:
- Ubuntu 9.10 (and win7)
- gcc (and visual studio 10 RC)
- Boost C++ (signals, function, bind)
- Irrlicht (->OpenGL, directX)
- Lua (for reading the config file)

entries.title: a bridge too far
entries.description:
you are challenged to cross all bridges

but is it... a bridge too far

entries.title: Artillery Isles
entries.description:
Artillery Isles is a realtime strategy game of sorts, in which the player must use the bases on his own islands to destroy the enemy's.

Capture more islands to produce more resources.

Here are the controls:
Left click to select a friendly island or rocket.
-- With selected friendly island or rocket --
Right click enemy island or rocket to launch or redirect rocket to attack
-- With selected friendly island only --
Right click neutral island to capture
Right click friendly island to repair
-- At any time --
Press Tab to cycle through friendly islands
Press P to Pause
Escape to Quit

I used my own framework, C/C++, SDL, SDL_mixer, and OpenGL to create this game. The Windows version probably requires that you have Visual Studio or the Microsoft Redistributable Runtime installed. Give it a shot!

Let me know if there are any crash bugs I can fix! Thanks, and have fun!

entries.title: Attack of the Canvey Island Monster
entries.description:
The Monster of Canvey Island has returned after fifty five years! 

Try to cause as much havok before she sadly suffocates due to lack of water.


Move her with the arrow keys, you can also smash cars in the foreground with the space bar.

The game was made in Game Maker v.8

Sadly I did run short of time, there were a lot of features which I cut at the last minute as they weren't entirely finished, such as people on fire (only thing that could hurt the create) knocking down buildings, as well as a variety of people, random sfx for the creature, a better background, plus much much more :)

Overall though I'm quite happy with the finished product even though it is simple :)

Also for those that don't read the story the creature was found in Canvey Island which is in Essex, UK. 
I hope you enjoy playing it!

entries.title: Baby Leviathan: Eat All Fishies
entries.description: Baby Leviathan likes to hunt the fishies hanging out by these islands.  Use the right and left arrow keys to swim around and catch them.

entries.title: Conquistador
entries.description:
My first Ludum Dare entry ever. This probably got about 26-28 hours of actual hands-on work. Unity is the best thing. :D

In this game you play an explorer in the Age of Sail. Outfit your ship and crew and set sail in search of uncharted islands, buried treasure, and mythical creatures.

It's kind of a short-form roguelike, I suppose. I didn't get to make as many events as I wanted to before the deadline, so I'll have to flesh that out in a later version. Event variety really makes all the difference, here.

-Josh

http://www.third-helix.com
twitter.com/invicticide

entries.title: Eden Island
entries.description:
The goal of the game is to create your own island and keep the ecosystem in balance.

Unfortunately we didn't get the chance to finish.  There is still a lot more stuff to go in that just didn't make it.  Hopefully, however, you'll get the concept of the game a bit.

Art by Germille, sprites and some music by bftd, coding by me.  To those saying it has to be a solo competition, it is never mentioned in the rules.

I've added a link to the source now.  After I fix some of the bugs present in the current version, I'll put up a repo on github.

entries.title: Flag Island
entries.description:
A CTF, platform, shooter game. Battle against the AI in an Island with guns each player. Made in one day for Ludum Dare 17 and for Experimental Gameplay Project: Repeat. 

Tools used in making this game: Game Maker 8, MS Paint, GIMP and Simple Particle Designer ( http://www.yoyogames.com/games/50901-simple-particle-designer )

Gameplay video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQOoRT4nCEs

entries.title: Giant Floating Island Adventure
entries.description:
You play as a young creature trying to escape from a giant floating island in the sky.
Arrows+Z
R to respawn from last checkpoint
Feedback appreciated.

entries.title: Infinite Deadly Islands Of Terror
entries.description:
This is a flash game, made with Flixel, so enjoy in your browser of choice!  Instructions are inside when you click on the big "HELP" on the title screen.  That sentence seems extremely unnecessary but there it is.  That sentence too really had no value.  I'll quit now.

Ooh, here's something worth saying!  I got online scores built into it before release, which makes me pretty awesome, so if you log into your Dumb Account at http://hamumu.com/ before playing, it will record your feats of skill.

I kept my journal at http://hamumu.com/journal.php (feel free to check the timestamps if you want to verify what was in the compo time!), so click on over and bear witness.

entries.title: Island Assault
entries.description:
Created with: Game Maker 8
Genre: Platformer

Controls
 Mouse: Go through menus
 Arrows: Movement
 P-key: Pause

Notes
 There are four levels for you to enjoy.
 Collect Coins and avoid the enemies.
 Be careful, if your HP gets to 0, you will die.
 Collect Health Kits to recover health.
 If you get out of the map, you die.

entries.title: Island Robotica
entries.description:
Story: You were a robot on a ship, you crash landed with your friends! (only one actually).  You have to rescue them.  Once you find a GPS (minimap) you can see their location and find them better.  Beware of the native wood chucks and snakes that spit!

The different versions are different resolutions.
You will need the .Net Framework 3.5
You will need the XNA Runtime 3.1

I was way too ambitious on the map size, 1024x1024 tiles, only playable part is about a quarter of that.  There are are lots of items scattered throughout the world to play with.  I didn't get nearly as far as I wanted to.  The music is awful, I know, the sound effects are pretty bad too.  Alas, it was my first time.

Different Windows downloads are different resolutions, only difference between them.  Should have made that more clear, sorry.

Basic controls: WASD / Arrow keys
Jump: space bar / 0 on number pad
Attack: F / left control / 1 on number pad
Change Weapons: 1, 2, 3
Use Acid: Enter
Save: F8
Load: F9
Cheat Mode / edit mode: F1

Known issues:
Sometimes jump doesn't register correctly.
Sometimes the slash screen displays for a couple of seconds before the Game Over or You Win screens.

entries.title: Island Survivor
entries.description:
This is my first entry. I learned a lot and I can't wait to do another one, although I'll have to wait the next one out. Good luck everyone!

EDIT: here's an alternate download link in case you can not download the file: 

http://www.mediafire.com/file/24zrmj52eur/island_survivor.zip

EDIT: Please note, you can win the game! You can find water from the crates as well as springs within the island if you explore the island enough.

entries.title: Island Warz
entries.description: Battle against the devilish Red Tribe amongst the islands that surround your home! Lead the Yellow Tribe to victory, each time on a (almost) totally random map!

entries.title: IslandsMUD
entries.description:
IslandsMUD is a multiplayer text game set on an island.

To play you must connect using telnet protocol to:

jplur.no-ip.org 5057

in windows command prompt type 'telnet jplur.no-ip.org 5057'

should work fine in linux, mac might have color emulation problems.

PuTTY telnet client will not work, other 'mud clients' should work fine.

in windows vista and 7 you will have to enable the default terminal program - cotroll panel:programs:Turn Windows Features on and off

KNOWN ISSUES:
passwords are saved as plaintext in the save file, for your security don't use an important password.

When you log in, you are sort of in limbo until you move to another room, and won't be able to attack or get attacked.

TIPS:

it shouldn't take more than a few minutes to gain a level or two, try attacking rats and alley cats at level 1.

entries.title: Mauritius
entries.description:
This is my submission to LD48.
You play a Dodo on the Island of Mauritius, trying to survive - WILL YOU MAKE IT? (Hint: probably no...).

Enjoy!

Download (First one is from google sites, second mirror supplied by ELI!! in hope it'll work... :-) )
Unzip to some directory and run "run.bat". Windows only, I'm afraid.
Be sure to read "readme.txt" if you have any problems.

The game was made using Visual C++ and the wonderful ClanLib.
Art was made using Paint.NET, GraphicsGale and Inkscape.
Music using Fruityloops and some old EMU soundfonts lying around on my hard drive.

Thanks!
Daniel

EDIT: I saw some people were having problems with OpenGL 2.
I fixed this and it now uses OpenGL 1.1 - Hope this helps! Thanks for the comments!

entries.title: Rescue the Stranded!
entries.description:
You're a BOAT!!! and you rescue people from islands.

(screenshot is slightly outdated)

EDIT: Source added. Yeah, D&D, since I'm pretty lazy.

entries.title: Simon Haigh's Pirates!
entries.description:
The king has commanded you, a daring pirate, to gather gold for him. 
He has given you 3 days to complete this mighty task.
You must slay monsters and other pirate ships in order to collect collect gold, and return to the king before time is up!

Controls

Arrow Keys: Move
Y/N/Enter: Selections
F4: Full Screen
Esc: Quit
Pageup: Speed game up (sometimes helpful for laptops)
Pagedown: Slow game down

See included .txt file for full instructions.

Enjoy!

entries.title: Super Island Colonizer
entries.description:
If you have DirectX problems, before reporting, please ensure you have this installed:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=2DA43D38-DB71-4C1B-BC6A-9B6652CD92A3&displaylang=en
I used Managed DX (DXSDK, not XNA), DirectSound, and Some WinAPI stuff (just for the Options window, to save some time.)
I wrote this up from an empty project, engine and all.

There is no pre-defined Win scinario.
You pick how you win from the "End Options" at the main menu, or you can pick a preset that i wrote into the game.

Have fun!

entries.title: The Noah's Ark

UPDATE: Mac version now available (Untested). Source code (Unity Project) also available.

entries.title: YARGH! Shake Yer Booty!
entries.description:
== UPDATE 2 ==
Wow, what a jackass... the previous uncompressed version contained the data for the engine test I sent out ( proof - http://www.stuckiegamez.co.uk/gamez/ludumdare/ld17/yargh-44.zip is the original demo on hour 44, it contains the same script set as this uncompressed version which was linked till two mins ago - http://www.stuckiegamez.co.uk/gamez/ludumdare/ld17/yargh-uncompressed.zip )
Thanks to shockedfrog for pointing it out!

What you can do, is mix and match the exes with the ( now four ) different zips, and it'll all work regardless.. so you could have, for instance, switched the virus scanner twitchy compressed exe in the original release, with the uncompressed one and it'd work fine. The engine has zero game logic, it's all in script so it wouldn't matter.

I've now updated the Uncompressed link with that containing the uncompressed exe PLUS the actual released data set.. and I've properly beat myself about the head for my stupidity.. perhaps next LD I'll actually release something without any bugger ups!

== UPDATE 2 ==

== UPDATE ==

I've added an uncompressed Win32 binary release as some virus scanners have been throwing hissy fits. I can only assume this is due to running the binary through UPX to compress it.

If there are any other issues, please let me know :)

== UPDATE ==

The one mega zip contains all data, an AMD64 Linux binary and a Win32 binary.

Engine source changes shall be up shortly once I get it committed to the branch. -- edit: They're up now, you can browse here: http://www2.xp-dev.com/sc/browse/42754/ or grab direct from SVN: http://svn2.xp-dev.com/svn/stuckie-SGZEngine/

Reposting the ReadMe here ( it's a ReadMe for a reason ;) )

YARGH! - Shake Yer Booty!
=========================

It's not quite complete.. there's a number of things missing but I've spent most of this weekend fighting with my engine and chasing obscure list bugs, sadly.
I'm releasing as is; there's still a lot there and it's amusing to see just how vicious the computer can actually be at times.
It's sheer bedlam!
Feel free to fiddle with the scripts as well ;)

I did atleast fix the bug that they'd go and absolutely destroy all the forts and mines immediately after starting ;)
Granted, you can't pillage the mines or forts ( it refused to pick up the buttons for some reason ) but hopefully this'll be a quick fix later.

I've enjoyed this Ludum Dare.. it's been a fun game to work on :)
Engine issues aside, of course...

Anyway, brief controls:
Left Click on your ship to select it.
Right Click moves it.
Arrow Keys or moving the mouse to the edge of the screen pans the camera.

While a unit is selected:
Hold LEFT Control and Right click an enemy unit to attack it.
Hold LEFT Shife and Right click on the ground to board/disembark from a ship ( depending on whether you're controlling a ship or man at the time )

Apologies that I didn't get this finished as much as I'd have liked...
And I shall say the usual - I'll try and continue it where possible!

Hope you at least enjoy wandering around and seeing the computer cause mayhem ;)

Oh, and you can change the screen resolution in the data/scripts/config.sgz ( just a text file )
640x480 is a bit cramped, 1024x768 was what it was developed in, but I'm sure you can ramp it up if you like.

Thanks :)
Steven Campbell

YOU ARE ISLAND.

entries.title: 10 Things to do when stranded on a Island
entries.description:
Here it is! My first commit to the grand ludum dare!

It's a light platformer, made with python and pygame primarely. 
Physics are done with my own physics module.
The basic idea is, that I wanted to see how much I could punish my processor with python and pygame, and boy did I succeed :P
Anyway you are the robot Monty, who is stranded on a Island. 
Your goal is gather ingredients for the best breakfast in the world. No more, no less :)
And of course you have to leave some Monty Python references when writing in python. A cookie to all who gets them :)

Controls are:
      a - to move right
      d - to move left
      space - to jump

The Linux binary is made on a 64-bit architecture, Windows executable will be up monday.

Looking forward to your judgement :)

Programs used:
        The GIMP

Libraries used:
        Cython
        Cxfreeze
        Pygame
        Py2exe

Edit:
HURAAA! Windows .exe is up!! It has a problem with running on wine but it should run on a windows pc. I must say that Py2exe isn't the most reliable software i.e. some of the level scripts have been messed up a bit. Especially platform positions. Guess I'm gonna go for C++ next time :)
Hope you can get it to work

Known issues:
Jumping - not as much an issue as an word of caution; the jump function can sometimes be a bit insensitive. So don't be afraid to spam the jump button :) Same goes for the move buttons.
